resource.chars:
The <s>internal shell <\s> Endostyle (c) resembles that of Salpa in 
its structure - It is as long as the branchial 
chamber - and lies in the dorsal sinus supported 
by a projecting ridge of the inner tunic - On 
each side of it below there is a longitudinal 
thickening which readily gives rise to the 
appearance of four dorsal bands or “undulated
[text]?” described by Savigny 
The Branchiae (u) are symmetrical, one on each 
side, and are composed of a network formed by 
longitudinal and vertical bars or laminae 
The vertical bars are outside - the longitudinal 
bars are at equal distances along their inner surface 
and are attached at the point of intersection 
The vertical bars are attached to the inner 
tunic at their upper and lower extremities 
for rest of their extent they are free 
The longitudinal bars (u. fig 3) are rather laminae 
flattened horizontally - slightly thickened at their
free edges and level along the upper surface 
of these edges with small teeth - They 
project anteriorly and posteriorly beyond the 
vertical bars 
Both systems of bars appeared to be tubular 
although no corpuscles were seen moving 
in opposite directions on the opposite sides -
The dorsal edges of the branchiae were 
separated by a space containing the thickened 
dorsal folds already mentioned - <s>[text?]<\s> 
The ventral edges - <s>[text?]<\s>
